titleStmt.title: Huon d'Auvergne, Bibliteca del seminario vescovile MS 32 (P), Annotations

div.note: Also transcribed by Holtus (2001), pp. 48-50, lines 1-109; Pasinus, 1-10; Peyron 1-16; Graf (1878) 1-72.

Rajna here places a description of the miniature: Min. 1. un re (tutto army) e p..t... altre figure; non intendo bene l'imagin/ Yug. dirige un psonag/ porge un breve/ ad un altro ch 'è/ inginocchiato/ forse l'invito di uon a corte
Numbers in Rajna's notebook are in pencil, added later.
Rajna: 2r. The manuscript began on a recto when he saw it, with 6 lines: 4 followed by a miniature, with two more following it. Here is the beginning of today's MS.
In Rajna's transcription, "y." somewhat after "el" above the line.

Holtus: los. "y" crossed out; Rajna: "caratt. più picc / forte aggiunte fatte / poi –i =" (marginal note). Rajna, note in right margin (sic). B: Anchois le haete la giant d[e] la [con]trie. T seems to be missing the verb, "odia"; an emeded reading might be anzo li (odi)a la zente de la contrà. Rajna note: "prima saa e così / parrebbe ancora / non credo scri tr /volz corregg". Rajna reverses these two lines, and uses numbering in the left margin to make clear their order. Crusca: al dilungo, vol. 1. https://books.google.com/books?id=qSoOZlKIdsgC&pg=PA92&lpg=PA92&dq=al+dilungo&source=bl&ots=SOFSiXoZ_x&sig=-sU48ACMCjMR2ymV8bcEdk_0MgI&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiB99m0iYzWAhXi64MKHdn7Bx4Q6AEIWTAJ#v=onepage&q=al%20dilungo&f=false Rajna, note "no del solito inchiostro / più nero delle giunte." At the beginning of his transcription, Rajna comments more on the various details of handwriting than toward the end. Rajna: seneschalcho, with the first "e" changed into "i" with a dot above and filled in. End of Holtus (2001) transcription. Rajna's notebook has "V" in the left margin, together with a crossed-out label, "IV." Rajna omits this line and later inserts in the right margin, thus beginning the line numbers of his transcription being off from the total. Rajna: messy note here, running over beginning of the following line: "O e in? / (non) mi pare" after having crossed out "Em?"; the "non" is written after, squeezed in; he clearly was not sure. The "E" covers the beginning of "Charlo" below. This line omitted in Rajna initially, inserted in right margin according to signal similar to "F." MS: ācorte, at the beginning of the line. prendea: the "e" is not clearly formed, missing the loop. However, here as elsewhere, if there is not a dot for the "i" I presume that it is an "e": thanks to M. Scattolini for this tip. Rajna: zos, with a mark in the margin; note on left side, referring to that mark: "qui un (a) lett. cancellz/ e sopra scritto un e, a.i./ Si dice legittima, legg. zosa." He has an "a" crossed out in the right margin. MS: baldovĩo; Rajna: baldovij, with a note in the left margin, "corr. in baldovĩo a.i." It is difficult to make sense of this line; I'm interpreting "each of them knocked his own down thoroughly," which requires understanding "le sovo" for MS: le sono (the parenthesis are for the emendation). However "n" and "v" are frequently difficult to distinguish; cf. Holtus 1985, p. XXXV.
Rajna initially misses this line and inserts it afterward in the margin. There are a couple of ways that this could be interpreted: first, "le roi... / armé, et avec toutes ses armes décorées d'une fleur de lys"; or, "[the king] is armed in weapons all decorated with a fleur-de-lys"; that is, the second word of the line could be a verb or the conjunction. elziso: this form seems to be from alzire/elzire; cf. <hi rend="italic"Aquilon de Bavière, "to kill"; the line then means, "that is, Huon, who wouldn't have killed him [Berardo] at all." Compare to B, where the verb is "to hate." This line does not make sense, since the copyist didn't understand the type of horse, "amoravis" and changed the term to something he knew! Compare with B. Rajna's copy shows a spot above "quelo," but it does not seem to be a dot to an "i" merely an imperfection in the paper. </note Illumination follows: Rajna, "2 giostra." In fact there is a view of one horsed man from the front, with a crown on his head and a sun on his chest in the center of the page; behind, to the right, there is a side view of a figure in grey on horseback with his lance at the attack position, with the same sun motif on the horse's caparison and a cape visible on his back. Rajna initially omits this line and adds it in the margin afterwards. B: selong lor coi[n]tenance. Nowhere else in this MS does any such form "sealonga" appear. Rajna initially skips this line and adds it later in the left margin. Rajna note: "li lom o loim, non /loin; ma / il segno sopra non / è un i troppo/ legittimo, ma rro/ poi (mi pare) un segno / p l'asta sotta / posta – se è / fu mal fatto." Rajna, note in margin: (sir, voglio) "a dove a dove"= a due a due; cf. "sove" = sue This line and the following are initially incorrectly ordered in Rajna, who then writes numbers in the left margin to indicate the correct order. sorprisse: there is a dot above the second "r," not above the following vowel. Rajna notes that he is not sure whether the MS reads "in" or "m." The strokes are linked. Illumination: two men under tree, one with horns and bells, the other with hat over his eyes. The MS has been scratched: ve:y is what the MS looks like. B: Quant vos forma (l. 421) Rajna has a mark after "chy" and before "ßve" that is unclear; it looks like a little caret. Perhaps this should read "ss[er]ve"? Rajna omits the "o" of "yo." There seems to be a line missing here; cf. B 444: Non ai ge soingn fors tout soul de celli (between this line and the following). Rajna omits the "u" of "nuy." These two omissions make one wonder about the "y" in line 444—should it be "yo"? MS: chre da more in B reads qui n'iert d'amore Rajna transcribes in reverse order this and the following line; he numbers in left margin to indicate the need to reorder. Rajna: ne piga. He underlines the word and has a line under the "p"; would seem to have been uncertain himself of the reading. B: emplie. Cf. Dante and the pilgrim's expressions of shame: e.g., Inf. 17.85-90. For "se tene y[n]tra ello" B: si tient traïe After the second "pensery," Rajna notes (sic). Rajna: anyda parla Rajna initially omits this line, then inserts it in the left margin. Rajna has a number of marks above this line that appear to be abbreviations: "razŷ...tōrmenta." Rajna initially omits this line, then inserts it in the left margin. B 549: Ja estes sire, et tot a vos atent The second half of this line is problematic; the hemistich reads in B: "Oïl, mon bon segnor." savye: where the ink is worn, it is frequently difficult to see the tail below the line; this could well read savie. However, under the light the tail can be seen. Here the tail is only visible with the ultraviolet light. Rajna reverses this line and the following, noting the correct order in the left margin. Rajna reads "guer" but the MS clearly reads a sapiate just at the edge of the burned portion.
